KH.content: belonging of genos [true citizens, philosophers, politicians] to proper place guarantees truth of its logos & action, different to Sophists who have no place, wander
KH.linkedContent: belonging of genos [true citizens, philosophers, politicians] to proper place guarantees truth of its logos & action, different to Sophists who have no place, wander

KH.content: Socrates speaks as true citizen while identifying w/ Sophist, feigns, simulacrum: tells you, you alone have place, gives you the floor > excludes himself by himself by giving back the word; no room for specialists of nonplace or simulacrum in the agora
KH.linkedContent: Socrates speaks as true citizen while identifying w/ Sophist, feigns, simulacrum: tells you, you alone have place, gives you the floor > excludes himself by himself by giving back the word; no room for specialists of nonplace or simulacrum in the agora

KH.content: Socrates as khōra, 3rd genus, for he only resembles the genus of those w/ no place
KH.linkedContent: Socrates as khōra, 3rd genus, for he only resembles the genus of those w/ no place

KH.content: Socrates effaces himself before those he addresses to receive all (pandekhēs), what kind of reception is this? Kantian intuitus derivativus or pure sensibility, the gift of hospitality?
KH.linkedContent: Socrates effaces himself before those he addresses to receive all (pandekhēs), what kind of reception is this? Kantian intuitus derivativus or pure sensibility, the gift of hospitality?

KH.content: w/ Socrates still sense of debt, gift & counter-gift: he is ready to receive the discourses of which he becomes welcoming > khōra glimpse beyond debt?
KH.linkedContent: w/ Socrates still sense of debt, gift & counter-gift: he is ready to receive the discourses of which he becomes welcoming > khōra glimpse beyond debt?

KH.content: Socrates puts himself in place of khōra (place itself, irreplaceable and unplaceable place), thus makes them, makes us talk, implacably [no choice] [see pp. 121-22 Socrates seems to program discourse of his addressees, who will speak?]
KH.linkedContent: Socrates puts himself in place of khōra (place itself, irreplaceable and unplaceable place), thus makes them, makes us talk, implacably [no choice] [see pp. 121-22 Socrates seems to program discourse of his addressees, who will speak?]

KH.content: is Socrates someone, something, play of proper names more abyssal than ever, “who are you, Khōra?”
KH.linkedContent: is Socrates someone, something, play of proper names more abyssal than ever, “who are you, Khōra?”

KH.content: oral maze inscribed in place which receives everything, Timaeus, addressed to “the one who, as we do, and before us [see p. 117], receives everything,” in this theory of receptions—Socrates
KH.linkedContent: oral maze inscribed in place which receives everything, Timaeus, addressed to “the one who, as we do, and before us [see p. 117], receives everything,” in this theory of receptions—Socrates

KH.content: wouldn’t Socrates, acc. Gorgias, if logos is already a penetrating supplement [here, Derrida keeps the metaphor, interrupts the dominating decision] be a sorcerer, a pharmakeus
KH.linkedContent: wouldn’t Socrates, acc. Gorgias, if logos is already a penetrating supplement [here, Derrida keeps the metaphor, interrupts the dominating decision] be a sorcerer, a pharmakeus

KH.content: Socrates’ desire to animate representation of political, of ideal State, by seeing it at war, in relation to death, outside of its graphical hallucination (immobility) which is the only way poets & Sophists can speak of politics [zoographic fiction, see p. 123]
KH.linkedContent: Socrates’ desire to animate representation of political, of ideal State, by seeing it at war, in relation to death, outside of its graphical hallucination (immobility) which is the only way poets & Sophists can speak of politics [zoographic fiction, see p. 123]

KH.content: Socrates can’t go outside his mythomimeticographic dream
KH.linkedContent: Socrates can’t go outside his mythomimeticographic dream

KH.content: Anselm? Gaunilon? Socrates? the greatest off all, must have been real
KH.linkedContent: Anselm? Gaunilon? Socrates? the greatest off all, must have been real

PP.content: Socrates’ viper bite, Socratic pharmakon like venom [quotes Meno (torpedo fish)]
PP.linkedContent: Socrates’ viper bite, Socratic pharmakon like venom [quotes Meno (torpedo fish)]

PP.content: acc. Plato in Laws, Socrates never left the city, never crossed borders, kept his word in the city, under surveillance of mother tongue, didn’t leave it open to errancy, to writing
PP.linkedContent: acc. Plato in Laws, Socrates never left the city, never crossed borders, kept his word in the city, under surveillance of mother tongue, didn’t leave it open to errancy, to writing

PP.content: Socrates turns poison into salvation by way of logos, gives hemlock an ontological effect: initiates one into contemplation of eidos and immortality of the soul
PP.linkedContent: Socrates turns poison into salvation by way of logos, gives hemlock an ontological effect: initiates one into contemplation of eidos and immortality of the soul

PP.content: Socrates knows well sculpture is an art of silence, son of sculptor, at first wanted to follow in his father’s footsteps (faire le métier de son père)
PP.linkedContent: Socrates knows well sculpture is an art of silence, son of sculptor, at first wanted to follow in his father’s footsteps (faire le métier de son père)

PP.content: as midwife, Socrates knows he will never be father, son, nor mother
PP.linkedContent: as midwife, Socrates knows he will never be father, son, nor mother

DPi.content: Socrates’ death: katēgoria (accusation), a theological one: he introduced new demons (hetera de daimonia kaina), daimonia sometimes gods but also lesser ones, revenants
DPi.linkedContent: Socrates’ death: katēgoria (accusation), a theological one: he introduced new demons (hetera de daimonia kaina), daimonia sometimes gods but also lesser ones, revenants

Gii.content: acc. Heidegger, Socrates is purest thinker of West, wrote nothing, placed himself in the draft—withdrawing movement, in Zug (pull) of withdrawal (des Entziehens)
Gii.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Socrates is purest thinker of West, wrote nothing, placed himself in the draft—withdrawing movement, in Zug (pull) of withdrawal (des Entziehens)

H.content: Socrates has characteristics of a foreigner [see p. 19]
H.linkedContent: Socrates has characteristics of a foreigner [see p. 19]

MPM.content: for Heidegger, Socrates is “purest thinker,” did nothing else but place himself in the draft, this is why he wrote nothing
MPM.linkedContent: for Heidegger, Socrates is “purest thinker,” did nothing else but place himself in the draft, this is why he wrote nothing

FWT.content: ostracism of madness, acc. E.R., begins, for Derrida, not w/ Descartes but w/ Socrates’ victory over the pre-Socratics
FWT.linkedContent: ostracism of madness, acc. E.R., begins, for Derrida, not w/ Descartes but w/ Socrates’ victory over the pre-Socratics

OTO.content: Nietzsche: dialectic is a symptom of decadence, especially in Socrates
OTO.linkedContent: Nietzsche: dialectic is a symptom of decadence, especially in Socrates

PSSS.content: Derrida’s Socratic-like “I know nothing,” doesn’t know where to put his knowing nothing (who authorizes his questions?)
PSSS.linkedContent: Derrida’s Socratic-like “I know nothing,” doesn’t know where to put his knowing nothing (who authorizes his questions?)

TN.content: Nancy’s “there is no ‘the’…” could deprive him of any conceptual determination, or hand over the discourse to irresponsible empiricism > Socrates has been teaching us this for years
TN.linkedContent: Nancy’s “there is no ‘the’…” could deprive him of any conceptual determination, or hand over the discourse to irresponsible empiricism > Socrates has been teaching us this for years

AD.content: Levinas proposes a teaching via welcoming that gives/receives something else, not ruse of master who feigns effacement behind figure of midwife
AD.linkedContent: Levinas proposes a teaching via welcoming that gives/receives something else, not ruse of master who feigns effacement behind figure of midwife

AD.content: maieutics, stuck in the same, teaches me nothing, only what is already in myself: même, egomet ipse, medisme, pouvoir savoir, property, gathers in itself (rassemble en lui-même) capacity & knowing
AD.linkedContent: maieutics, stuck in the same, teaches me nothing, only what is already in myself: même, egomet ipse, medisme, pouvoir savoir, property, gathers in itself (rassemble en lui-même) capacity & knowing

WOG.content: mediation through Nietzsche [re: Greeks] not constant—often ironic; PC very ironic about Nietzsche’s image of Socrates
WOG.linkedContent: mediation through Nietzsche [re: Greeks] not constant—often ironic; PC very ironic about Nietzsche’s image of Socrates

SPEC.content: Plato accuses Aristophanes in Apology, Alicibiades defends Socrates in Symposium; Plato is behind Socrates, or in front, as a lawyer: here is the martyr, he’s innocent, he’s judging you
SPEC.linkedContent: Plato accuses Aristophanes in Apology, Alicibiades defends Socrates in Symposium; Plato is behind Socrates, or in front, as a lawyer: here is the martyr, he’s innocent, he’s judging you
